[snip...]

> >         Again this brings home to me that any evolving software technique
> >really needs functional, automatic modularity before it has any hope of
> >breaking into the BIG problems.  Modularity entails a trade off very like
> >(5) in that the presence of modularity increases the size of the overall
> >search space (adding choices about how to define modules) but hugely
> >decreases the size of the parts that are considered at one time (e.g. each
> >modules fitness landscape is much, much smaller than the overall fitness
> >landscape.).
> >
> >
>In the mean time it's a good idea to investigate the limits of direct
>encoding techniques such as NEAT. With a great many experiments and all
>ideas exhausted research can them move on to modular or indirect
>approaches, using the best direct encoding technques as a benchmark.  I
>also think that NEAT could form the core of an indirect encoding
>technique in the future, finding sub-solutions that can then be
>recombined into larger solutions. I think I just walked into that trap
>of thinking in a 'divide and conquer' / engineering manner again :)

I'm not sure that I agree.

Hmm, let me rephrase, I agree that NEAT is an exciting technique and well 
worthy of all the exploration we can get.

But..., I'm not sure that the progression to modular systems is necessarily 
a _consequence_ of sufficient non-modular research.

Maybe this is the same doubt as you imply in your final sentence?

I'm also not sure I necessarily equate the "indirect" with "modular".  I 
mean there is some quite solid thought suggesting that indirect encoding is 
a major approach to modularity (e.g. in nature).  Or even, reversing the 
viewpoint, that by the time you've added enough bells-and-whistles to 
support modularity, you will find the representations no longer very 
direct.  But I think it's worth taking care to keep the concepts separate 
for the moment...

>Anyway I have serious doubts about how well indirect techniques can work
>without much faster computers

Hmm, you are of course right, but I would also argue that CPU has made 
great strides in the last few years, and nobody has yet really plumbed the 
depths of what's practical at our current level.  That and the fact that 
Moore's law catches up faster than one thinks, so there's no harm trying to 
have a few "impractical" approaches ready for the year after next.

>  or at least enough money to buy computers
>fast enough. e.g. see
>http://www.geek.com/news/geeknews/2004Jul/bch20040730026275.htm
>
>Anyone got $3.5 million to spare? :)

Sure, I'll put it in the mail, oh, wait, sorry, I need to buy some socks.

Grid computing _can_ get you that sort of CPU for free.  OK, not "free" you 
have to work for it and you do have to hit exactly the right note on the PR 
front.

Grid computing also adapts most neatly (no pun intended) to an "islands" 
approach to subpopulations.  Which is another take on that whole 
species/sub-species discussion in my earlier post.
